title: Helen Cooper (literary scholar)
text:
Elizabeth Helen Cooper, (born 6 February 1947), known as Helen Cooper, is a British literary scholar. From 2004 to 2014, she was <a href="Professor%20of%20Medieval%20and%20Renaissance%20English%2C%20Cambridge%20University">Professor of Medieval and Renaissance English</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Cambridge">University of Cambridge</a>, and a <a href="Fellow%20%28Oxbridge%29">fellow</a> of <a href="Magdalene%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Magdalene College, Cambridge</a>.
Early life and education.
Cooper was born on 6 February 1947 in <a href="Nottingham">Nottingham</a>, England. Her parents were <a href="Percy%20Edward%20Kent">Percy Edward Kent</a>, an exploration geologist, and Betty Kent. She was educated at <a href="Nottingham%20Girls%27%20High%20School">Nottingham Girls' High School</a>, an all-girls <a href="Independent%20school%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">independent school</a>. She studied at <a href="New%20Hall%2C%20Cambridge">New Hall, Cambridge</a>, graduating with a Bachelor of Arts (BA) degree in 1968: as per tradition, her BA was promoted to a <a href="Master%20of%20Arts%20%28Oxbridge%20and%20Dublin%29">Master of Arts</a> (MA Cantab) degree. She remained at New Hall to undertake postgraduate study, one of her <a href="Doctoral%20advisor">supervisors</a> was <a href="Jack%20A.%20W.%20Bennett">Jack A. W. Bennett</a>, and she completed her Doctor of Philosophy (PhD) degree in 1971. Her <a href="doctoral%20thesis">doctoral thesis</a> was titled "The mediaeval background of English Renaissance pastoral literature".
Academic career.
From 1971 to 1974, Cooper was a <a href="junior%20research%20fellow">junior research fellow</a> at <a href="New%20Hall%2C%20Cambridge">New Hall, Cambridge</a>. In 1978, she was elected a <a href="Fellow%20%28Oxbridge%29">fellow</a> at <a href="University%20College%2C%20Oxford">University College, Oxford</a>: she was the first woman to become a fellow at the formerly all-male college. During this time, she was also a lecturer in English at the <a href="University%20of%20Oxford">University of Oxford</a>, rising to become chair of its Faculty of English. In 1996, she was awarded a <a href="Title%20of%20Distinction">Title of Distinction</a> by the University of Oxford as <a href="Professor%20%28highest%20academic%20rank%29">Professor</a> of English Language and Literature. From 2000 to 2002, she was also the president of the <a href="New%20Chaucer%20Society">New Chaucer Society</a>.
In 2004, Cooper moved to the <a href="University%20of%20Cambridge">University of Cambridge</a>, having been appointed to its <a href="Professor%20of%20Medieval%20and%20Renaissance%20English%20%28Cambridge%29">Chair of Medieval and Renaissance English</a>. She was also elected a <a href="professorial%20fellow">professorial fellow</a> of <a href="Magdalene%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Magdalene College, Cambridge</a>. She retired from full-time academics in 2014, and was appointed <a href="Professor%20Emeritus">Professor Emeritus</a> by Oxford and made a Life Fellow at Magdalene College.
Her research is in the continuity of literature across the <a href="Middle%20Ages">Middle Ages</a> and <a href="Renaissance">Renaissance</a>. Her latest book is "Shakespeare and the Medieval World", published in 2010 as part of the <a href="Arden%20Shakespeare">Arden Shakespeare</a> series.
Personal life.
In 1970, she married Michael Cooper, a fellow academic: he died in 2007. Together they had two daughters.
Honours.
In 2001, Cooper was awarded an <a href="honorary%20degree">honorary</a> <a href="Doctor%20of%20Letters">Doctor of Letters</a> (DLitt) degree by <a href="Washington%20and%20Lee%20University">Washington and Lee University</a>. In 2006, she was elected a <a href="Fellow%20of%20the%20British%20Academy">Fellow of the British Academy</a> (FBA), the United Kingdom's <a href="national%20academy">national academy</a> for the humanities and social sciences. In 2016 she delivered the British Academy's Sir Israel Gollancz Memorial Lecture.
